A unique game that combines both fighting and puzzle-solving skills, with the icing on the cake of the co-op mode in which you can play with up to 3 friends to complete the levels, using both your wits and teamwork. At first i thought it could be another boring 'kill and solve this thing to proceed to the next level' game, but damn i'm happy that i were so wrong.  The puzzles are infact part that has been very well integrated into the battleground of your levels, it means that you will have to both fight and use a spirit with the shape of a sphere (your main tool to solve these puzzles) in order to beat certain kind of bosses, or just to open a door while running from a swarm of monsters or either avoid lethal environment present in the level, or even activate some for your aid.  Even the fighting part itself is pretty nice, 4 different gladiators to choose from, each with their own weapons and unique skills that you will earn as long as you progress into the game by completing the levels themselves and their respective timer to beat, or some 'challenges' which will test your skills furthermore.  The requirements of this game are also kinda flexible, at the minimum of 2 GB ram i could've run this pretty smoothly, of course decreasing video quality, but with even more recent computers it can run decently at higher settings.  One of the best university projects that made into Steam, made with the Unity engine. Definitely a worthy game.

Lately I became a happy owner of 3 wireless game controllers.  Naturally I started collecting (more like 'hoarding') locally cooperative games. FORCED is one of the first i bought.  It was on sale, and had excellent reviews, so being always on a lookout for some local mp games I thought I'll give it a try.   It was an excellent purchase.  My buddy and I have sat through it's levels on numerous nights, from dusk till dawn, and couldn't get enough. Surprisingly though game is easy at first but very challenging in longer run. First few levels are kinda slow-paced and trivial, You get to know your characters and their capabilities, and you don't really care for speedrunning, nor challenges, But what's brilliant about this game, is that it makes you go back and revisit levels and play them through perfectly, for sake of progressing through other hard levels.  FORCED is a story of skill on a very interesting level. Game such as this- easy to play, hard to master- is not a very common thing these days, so I would recommend it to anyone. Playing with a buddy is greatly rewarding experience, so I'd recommend playing it in coop.

This is a very challenging action game with a lot of puzzles in the mix. Not the most difficult game you could be playing but still very difficult, Forced has you playing through a variety of challenges, from puzzles to boss battles to time limits. This was my first game to get 100% achievement status on, and I got that status within 12 hours, so obviously, the game is short. However, I have to admit the game was absurdly challenging and required a lot of patience and planning to play it properly.  Keyboard/mouse controls are great, so I did not bother trying out a gamepad, but there is Xbox 360 controller support. The space key is used for multiple actions, however, and I often had to restart levels because I accidentally called the orb when I was trying to skip dialogue. Not a big deal, mind you. I just found that slightly annoying.  The game could be longer, and I wish there were more character customization options. There are no visual customizations, but what I would really like to see are some more skill and stat choices. I felt like only a few of the skills and stats were worth using. Overall, the game was a lot of fun, and it is worth full price to me, but it is far from a perfected experience.

So bought this game as a 4 pack with some friends. Totally worth it! It's a sorta hack/slash rpg'ish puzzle game. You control 1 of 4 different characters (hammer, bow, shield, daggers) each has their own set of skills, passives, and playstyles. You work with your friends to navigate innovative maps and figure out puzzles all with the help of a little orb spirt guy. Every person can call this orb to their position so it can be trolly if everyone is spamming. It requires a great deal of communication as it sometimes requires you to bounce the orb from person to person but without letting it hit objects (part of the puzzle). I highly recommend you pick this up in a 4 pack and play with friends over voice chat as it can be very fun, quirky, rewarding, and frustrating all in one but there is sense of accomplishment similar to when you first beat a boss in an MMO when you nail a puzzle while 3 of your friends are dead and you are teetering on life. The simple combat systems works perfectly as there is plenty of other object happening on the screen to keep you active and always thinking.  There isn't a game out there like this on the market that I am aware. Anyone who plays with friends should pick this up.

This is a pretty cool game, with some annoying issues. You (and a few others if you play online) must complete a series of challenges to advance. You're afforded the choice of four different weapons - they all play quite differently and come with their own set of abilities and buffs. And each challenge gives you up to three crystals, and when you get a number of crystals, you get new abilities.   It's a pretty unique take on this type of game, as you can't really 'grind' to level up, at most you can get a couple new buffs to help yourself out, if you master previous challenges. Because of this, it comes down more to strategy and skill, and can become quite fun in some segments.   Sometimes, however, things can be a pain in the butt. Certain challenges or bosses seem to combine the most annoying parts of the game all in one, in seemingly unfair ways. And though the game says that it's balanced for either 1-4 players, more players simply make it easier in so many ways.   That said, I really enjoyed the game, when it wasn't being irritating, and would recommend it to others who are looking for a challenging title to play along with friends.

Forced is an arena challenge/puzzle game with co-op than can suck out your time like nothing else. In this game you're a tribesmen trying to earn your freedom , being helped by the spirit master, sorting through several challenges (total of 25 levels including final boss) to earn power. Each time you complete a level you earn a crystal, if you complete it again doing the time challenge or the skill challenge, some are really hard even playing with 3 friends, what's unfair is than some of the skills and passives require a lot of crystals, being the final passive of each class requiring 75, by then you would have completed the game 100% so why would you keep playing?. The 4 classes are spirit blades some sort of assasin, Volcanic hammer the warrior, The Frost Shield being the paladin and the Storm bow being the archer (obviously), you can swap classes anytime before tackling on a level without any kind of penalty. The levels are either purify temples, destroy stuff, kill stuff, and kill moar stuff, all of them requires strategical use of the spirit mentor which can heal you or aid you depending which shrines you use him to activate, some are really fun like the arena with the spinning laser in the centre, and challenge don't take cover from it. The game is great fun with friends but frustrating very frustrating if you wish to proceed all the way to winning the game, you can grab it during sales fairly cheap to try with friends

A fun and challenging co-op action/puzzle game. It's not really an RPG such as Torchlight II or Diablo, but is instead focused on having four different weapon classes to take on challenges known as 'Trials'. Completing each trial will unlock crystals that automatically unlock abilities across your weapons. You can change abilities and weapons before any trial, so no need to worry about taking the wrong things. There is also this orb that you can control and is the main aspect of pretty much all puzzles, and even some combat.  Bought during sale. I really enjoyed this game. Highly reccomended to play if you have any friends to play with, as it can be a bit dull alone. It performed better than my expectations, and was well worth my money.  Obligatory pro's and cons:  + Really fun for 2-4 players + Handles multiplayer scaling and progresses in difficulty very well. + Fun combat and classes + OH GOSH SO MANY ENEMIES TO KEEP IN CHECK WHILE TRYING TO CONTROL THIS ORB AND BEING CHASED BY A GIANT SPINNING DEATH LAZOR  - A bit dull alone - Slight lagspikes at times during multiplayer (could be my internet, though) - Orb-controlling is slightly annoying when you're not co-operating properly in multiplayer. - OH GOSH SO MANY ENEMIES TO KEEP IN CHECK WHILE HAVING TO CONTROL THIS ORB ACROSS A GIANT SPINNING DEATH LAZOR FIFTEEN TIMES  Final score: 8/10 so far. Reccomended to buy during sales, but 14€ is worth it if you're into this kind of games.

This was a failed attempt to merge 3 different genres: RPG, Top down hack-and-slash, and co-op puzzle solving. Its claim to fame is that players are supposed to cooperate in puzzle solving while being assaulted by waves of enemies. However, these systems work against each other. The AI enemies are not threatening enough to pose as a threat; they become a mere annoyance as you try to solve the puzzles to finish the level. Likewise, the co-op puzzles aren't very good either; instructions and tutorials are vague, but if you manage to guess-and-check your way to the solution, you'll find many levels that repeat the same type of puzzle. The co-op system doesn't really work with puzzles; you'll be fighting your friends for your idea of problem solving, instead of collaborating to complete the challenge. Connectivity is horrid, and although the game features 4 different classes, they feel somewhat similar against the same dull foes. 3/10

Up front, Forced appears to do a good job of blending Guantlet arcade-style smash'm up with ARPG elements--added to with a touch of simple puzzle solving. Sadly, the game idea that Forced is needs much more...  For Single-Players, or Solo-Play:  The attempt at a story is more of a hinderance and should've been left out almost all together. The general direction in design is pretty spotty and left me feeling non-plussed several times as I attempted to learn one mechanic or another. The challenges are a bit too tightly setup, and are limited in scope. Thus, completing challenges unlocks abilites, and so you find yourself 'forced' to wait for much good deal of the fun the game can provide, repeating the same stages over and over. Also, a key element in the game, your spirit mentor, could be so much more interesing. Last but not least, the graphics really could be better, indie or not.   As much as Forced is a solid idea, the production quality and execution are both sadly lackluster...and that voice acting...yikes.

I can't speak to how this game plays in a co-op setting, as of July 2014, there is no one left playing this game anymore - but I can speak to its single-player campaign.  This game is simply not fun if you play by yourself. Everything is balanced for multiple players, after the first couple trials, the game simply becomes tedious if you're trying to do everything on your own.  While I appreciate a good challenge, this game focuses on the wrong place. The puzzles are brain-dead easy, and the single-player challenge simply comes from throwing an ever-increasing amount of mobs at you. If it was possible to out-run these enemies and kite their numbers down, it would be manageable, but as they all move faster than you and, in many levels, respawn faster than you can kill them it makes the singleplayer game completely unenjoyable.
Was fun initially, but then became too difficult to enjoy. Retrying a level 3...4...5 times -- OK. When you can't beat a level after 20 tries, it's time to quit playing the game.

I don't even know why I bought this game, maybe it was shiny, who knows.   What I do know is this game is unfinished. I say charater but your just a gladiator without a name or face that wears different armor depending on what the lobby leader ♥♥♥♥♥es at you to be. It's a nice feature that you can change classes at whim so there's no commitment to a certain role. With the human husk of a character the story is terrible and the meat of the game is left to repetitive arenas one after the other.   Meh, the game's just boring, noticibly unpolished, and requires multiplayer for fun. Also multiplayer is buggy and won't connect at times.   So what can you do, play a better game at least.
